channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: First Baptist Dallas Church Damaged by Fire
item.description: The roof of a 19th-century part of the First Baptist Dallas Church in the city’s downtown appeared to have collapsed.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Global Court Says Israel’s Occupation of Territories Violates International Law
item.description: The advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice is the first time the court has laid out its stance on the issue.

item.title: Four travel gems in France: A guide through lavender fields, sleepy ski villages, and the region’s ‘Hamptons’
item.description: The following four regions are no secret; the French, and some smart Brits, have long understood their appeal.

item.title: Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, a Champion for Progressive Causes, Dies at 74
item.description: Ms. Lee, a Democrat who represented a district in the Houston area for nearly three decades, said in June that she had pancreatic cancer.

item.title: Outage for Microsoft Users Knocks Out Systems for Airlines and Hospitals in Chaotic Day
item.description: Companies across the world reported disruptions, citing technical issues from a cybersecurity software update.

item.title: Affordable travel is to blame for Europe’s overtourism problem, spoiling its most sought-after cities like Barcelona, Amsterdam and Athens
item.description: Mass tourism isn't a new phenomenon, but it’s reached a tipping point in Europe where locals are increasingly bearing the brunt of it.

item.title: Gunman at Rally for Former President Trump Had Drone in Car
item.description: Investigators have information that suggests a man intent on assassinating former President Donald J. Trump flew the device over the campaign event location on the day of the shooting.

item.title: Death of Vietnam’s Top Leader Raises Questions of Succession
item.description: The country’s political workings are notably opaque, but for now the president, who was until recently minister of public security, is carrying out the duties of general secretary.

item.title: CEO at cybersecurity firm that caused a global outage forgot to apologize
item.description: The lack of contrition likely stems from the IT sector’s longstanding struggle to relate in a more personalized and less robotic way with the general public.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi Endorsed ‘Open’ Nomination Process if Biden Drops Out
item.description: The former House speaker and fellow California lawmakers were discussing the Democratic Party’s stressful state of affairs.

item.title: The Bangladesh Protests, in Photos and Videos
item.description: Students, armed mainly with sticks, have been demonstrating for days against a quota system for government jobs they consider unfair. Dozens have died in the violence.

item.title: Billionaire’s son resolves feud over inheritance
item.description: Alberto Safra claimed his father, who suffered from Parkinson’s disease, lacked the mental capacity to execute the three new wills that disinherited him

item.title: Secluded in Rehoboth, Biden Stews at Allies’ Pressure to Drop Out of the Race
item.description: As he recovers from Covid, the president has grown resentful toward Democratic congressional leaders and former President Barack Obama.

item.title: Blinken Says Gaza Cease-Fire Deal Is ‘Inside the 10-Yard Line’
item.description: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, was more cautious as both spoke ahead of next week’s visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

item.title: Apple and Walmart banking partner Green Dot fined $44 million by the Federal Reserve
item.description: Green Dot Bank, the banking-as-a-Service partner to some of America’s biggest companies agreed to pay the fine for policies they say they fixed years ago.
